user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of version:
```c
static int version(void)
{
	char ver_def[16], ver_dyn[16];

	snprintf(ver_def, sizeof(ver_def), "%d.%d.%d",
		 METAL_VER_MAJOR,
		 METAL_VER_MINOR,
		 METAL_VER_PATCH);

	snprintf(ver_dyn, sizeof(ver_dyn), "%d.%d.%d",
		 metal_ver_major(), metal_ver_minor(), metal_ver_patch());

	return (strcmp(ver_def, METAL_VER) +
		strcmp(ver_dyn, metal_ver()));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function version:
#define METAL_VER_MAJOR 1
...
#define METAL_VER_MINOR 8
...
#define METAL_VER_PATCH 0
...
#define METAL_VER "1.8.0"
...
int metal_ver_major(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_MAJOR;
}
...
int metal_ver_minor(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_MINOR;
}
...
int metal_ver_patch(void)
{
	return METAL_VER_PATCH;
}
...
const char *metal_ver(void)
{
	return METAL_VER;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is modified in the provided code. The function version(void) has no parameters. The only pointers involved are (a) automatic arrays ver_def and ver_dyn passed to snprintf — snprintf modifies the objects pointed to (the arrays) but does not modify the pointer parameter itself (and MISRA Rule 17.8 permits modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter), and (b) calls to strcmp and metal_ver() use const char * and do not modify their pointer arguments. The helper functions metal_ver_major/minor/patch take no parameters and simply return macros. Therefore there are no code fragments in this snippet that appear to violate Rule 17.8 and nothing else needs investigation for this rule.
